Sequence.name: Wscal.Randomization
Sequence.documentation: A specialized version of ToleranceValueType used to indicate the degree of randomization required. In this use, the startafter and startbefore attributes indicate the range of the starting times.

Sequence.name: Wscal.RecurType
Sequence.documentation: This value type is used to identify properties that contain a recurrence rule specification. From RFC5545 section 3.3.10. Recurrence Rule.

Enumerated.name: freq
Enumerated.documentation: The freq rule part identifies the type of recurrence rule. Valid values include SECONDLY, to specify repeating events based on an interval of a second or more; MINUTELY, to specify repeating events based on an interval of a minute or more; HOURLY, to specify repeating events based on an interval of an hour or more; DAILY, to specify repeating events based on an interval of a day or more; WEEKLY, to specify repeating events based on an interval of a week or more; MONTHLY, to specify repeating events based on an interval of a month or more; and YEARLY, to specify repeating events based on an interval of a year or more.

DateTime.name: until
DateTime.documentation: The until rule part defines a date/time value that bounds the recurrence rule in an inclusive manner. If the value specified by until is synchronized with the specified recurrence, this date/time becomes the last instance of the recurrence. Only one of until or count may be used in a single RecurType instance. Constraint: The choice of either LocalDateTime or UTCDateTime as the datatype shall be consistent with the choice made within the associated AvailabilityType.DateTimeInterval and VavailabilityType.DateTimeInterval.

Integer.name: count
Integer.documentation: The COUNT rule part defines the number of occurrences at which to range-bound the recurrence. Only one of until or count may be used in a single RecurType instance.

Integer.name: interval
Integer.documentation: The interval rule part contains a positive integer representing at which intervals the recurrence rule repeats. The default value is "1", meaning every second for a SECONDLY rule, every minute for a MINUTELY rule, every hour for an HOURLY rule, every day for a DAILY rule, every week for a WEEKLY rule, every month for a MONTHLY rule, and every year for a YEARLY rule. For example, within a DAILY rule, a value of "8" means every eight days.

Array.name: bySecond
Array.documentation: Specifies a sequence of seconds within a minute -- 0..60.

Array.name: byMinute
Array.documentation: Specifies a sequence of minutes within an hour -- 0..59.

Array.name: byHour
Array.documentation: Specifies a sequence of hours within a day -- 0..23.

Array.name: byMonthDay
Array.documentation: Specifies a sequence of day numbers within a month. Valid values are 1 to 31 or -31 to -1. For example, -10 represents the tenth to the last day of the month.

Array.name: byYearDay
Array.documentation: Specifies a sequence of day numbers within a year. Valid values are 1 to 3366 or -366 to -1. For example, -1 represents the last day of the year.

Array.name: byWeekNo
Array.documentation: A sequence of week-numbers of a year, based on the definitions in ISO.8601.2004.

Array.name: byMonth
Array.documentation: A sequence of month numbers in a year -- 1..12.

Array.name: bySetPos
Array.documentation: The bysetpos rule part specifies a sequence of values that corresponds to the nth occurrence within the set of recurrence instances specified by the RecurType instance.

Enumerated.name: wkst
Enumerated.documentation: Specifies the day on which the workweek starts.

Sequence.name: Wscal.WeekdaySpecType
Sequence.documentation: Specifies a week day and a recurrence number. For example, within a MONTHLY rule: +1,MO represents the first Monday within the month, whereas -1,MO represents the last Monday of the month.

Enumerated.name: dow
Enumerated.documentation: Specifies a day of the week.

Integer.name: num
Integer.documentation: If present, this indicates the nth occurrence of a specific day within the MONTHLY or YEARLY RecurType.

Sequence.name: Wscal.AttachType
Sequence.documentation: This class represents data in the domain of concern over some interval of time.

Sequence.name: Wscal.AvailabilityType
Sequence.documentation: This class expresses the range of times in which an Interval or Sequence can be Scheduled.

Sequence.name: rRule
Sequence.documentation: A recurrence rule specification as defined in RFC5545, (2009) Section 3.3.10.

Array.name: exDate
Array.documentation: A set of one or more exception dates that override the sequence specified in the rRule attribute, derived from RFC5545, (2009) Section 3.8.5.1

Sequence.name: availInterval
Sequence.documentation: This serves as the template "anchoring" interval that the recurrence rule (stored in rRule) is evaluated against. At instantiation time the choice must be made whether to express the interval as a UTCDateTimeInterval or a LocalDateTimeInterval.

Sequence.name: Wscal.GluonType
Sequence.documentation: A GluonType influences the serialization of IntervalTypes in a sequence. A GluonType is often used as a pointer to the beginning interval in a sequence, although in general it can point to any interval in a sequence, or simply describe an isolated interval.

Array.name: relation
Array.documentation: This role links a GluonType instance to a specific interval within a sequence (typically the beginning interval). The target RelationLink instance would have a RelationLink.relationship value of CHILD, and would identify the interval with the RelationLink.link attribute. (This association redefines the relation association between the IntervalType Class (see Clause 5.7.3.2.7) and the RelationLink Class (see Clause 5.7.3.2.8).)

Array.name: vavailability
Array.documentation: The specification of the time span and pattern of intervals that defines a sequence.

Sequence.name: Wscal.IntervalType
Sequence.documentation: This class represents an interval of time that attaches to a collection of data pertinent to the interval.

String.name: instanceUid
String.documentation: Unique identifier to the interval instance.

Sequence.name: timeReference
Sequence.documentation: The time reference for an interval which includes some combination of start, duration, and end.

Sequence.name: tolerance
Sequence.documentation: The tolerance for the associated timeReference.

Array.name: attach
Array.documentation: Associates a set of AttachType data with this IntervalType.

Sequence.name: Wscal.RelationLink
Sequence.documentation: The RelationLink class serves to link a set of intervals together, in support of a linked-list method of creating a sequence. It is also used to link a GluonType instance to a specific interval within a sequence, typically used to point to the beginning interval of a sequence.

String.name: gap
String.documentation: An optional attribute to specify a gap in time between one interval and the next. The default interpretation is a value of zero.

String.name: link
String.documentation: The unique identifier of the interval being linked to.

Enumerated.name: relationship
Enumerated.documentation: The kind of link (see the RelationshipType enumeration).

Enumerated.name: temporalRelationship
Enumerated.documentation: The specification of the temporal relation of one interval to the interval being linked to. By default, this will be FinishToStart, meaning the next interval immediately begins after the previous interval.

Sequence.name: Wscal.ToleranceValueType
Sequence.documentation: A tolerance value is a set of durations which indicate the allowed tolerance for the indicated value. Note that there may be many tolerance values associated with a Duration.

String.name: durationLong
String.documentation: Indicates by how much the performance Duration may exceed the Duration specified in the information exchange. Duration Long Tolerance SHALL NOT be used when Start and End Tolerances are both specified.

String.name: durationShort
String.documentation: Indicates by how much the performance Duration may fall short of the Duration specified in the information exchange. Duration Short Tolerance SHALL NOT be used when Start and End Tolerances are both specified.

String.name: endAfter
String.documentation: Indicates how far after the scheduled end time the requested service may commence, for example, if a service that ends at 2:01 is compliant with a request to end at 2:00

String.name: endBefore
String.documentation: Indicates how far before scheduled end time may end, for example, if a service that ends at 1:57 is compliant with a request to end at 2:00

String.name: precision
String.documentation: Whatever the time tolerance above, there is some minimum time that is considered significant. When used in Tolerance, precision defines the tracking and reporting requirements for a service.

String.name: startAfter
String.documentation: Indicates how far after the requested start time the requested service may commence , for example, if a service that begins at 2:01 is compliant with a request to start at 2:00

String.name: startBefore
String.documentation: Indicates how far before the requested start time the requested service may commence, for example if a service that begins at 1:57 is compliant with a request to start at 2:00

Sequence.name: Wscal.VavailabilityType
Sequence.documentation: The VavailabilityType class is intended to establish a baseline range of time to scope a sequence. The class can specify a start time and an end time or duration, using the timeRange attribute. If "start" is not present, then the start time is unbounded. If "end" or "duration" are not present, then the end time is unbounded. Within the specified time period, availability defaults to an interpretation of "not availableâ€, except for any time periods corresponding to associated AvailabilityType instances.

String.name: granularity
String.documentation: The finest precision that can be used to define times, such as the value of dtStart or duration

Sequence.name: timeRange
Sequence.documentation: The span of time that bounds the associated sequence of intervals defined using one or more AvailabilityType instances. At instantiation time the choice must be made whether to express the interval as a UTCDateTimeInterval or a LocalDateTimeInterval.

Integer.name: priority
Integer.documentation: Integer value from 1 to 9. Higher numbers have lower priority per RFC5545.

Array.name: availability
Array.documentation: The specification of a single interval, and optionally the rules for the pattern of intervals that constitute a sequence.

Enumerated.name: Wscal.FreqRecurType
Enumerated.documentation: Used to identify the unit of time to be used in specifying the frequency of a recurring event.

Unsigned.name: SECONDLY
Unsigned.documentation: Used to specify repeating events based on an interval of a second or more.

Unsigned.name: MINUTELY
Unsigned.documentation: Used to specify repeating events based on an interval of a minute or more.

Unsigned.name: HOURLY
Unsigned.documentation: Used to specify repeating events based on an interval of an hour or more.

Unsigned.name: DAILY
Unsigned.documentation: Used to specify repeating events based on an interval of a day or more.

Unsigned.name: WEEKLY
Unsigned.documentation: Used to specify repeating events based on an interval of a week or more.

Unsigned.name: MONTHLY
Unsigned.documentation: Used to specify repeating events based on an interval of a month or more.

Unsigned.name: YEARLY
Unsigned.documentation: Used to specify repeating events based on an interval of a year or more.

Enumerated.name: Wscal.RelationshipType
Enumerated.documentation: Specifies the type of hierarchical relationship associated with the calendar component specified by the property. The parameter value can be PARENT, to indicate that the referenced calendar component is a superior of calendar component; CHILD to indicate that the referenced calendar component is a subordinate of the calendar component; or SIBLING to indicate that the referenced calendar component is a peer of the calendar component. If this parameter is not specified on an allowable property, the default relationship type is PARENT.

Unsigned.name: PARENT
Unsigned.documentation: Indicates that the referenced calendar component is a superior of calendar component - default

Unsigned.name: CHILD
Unsigned.documentation: Indicates that the referenced calendar component is a subordinate of the calendar component. For example, a GluonType would have a CHILD relationship with the IntervalType it is pointing to.

Unsigned.name: SIBLING
Unsigned.documentation: Indicates that the referenced calendar component is a peer of the calendar component. For example, an IntervalType would have a SIBLING relationship with another IntervalType it is pointing to.

Enumerated.name: Wscal.TemporalRelationshipType
Enumerated.documentation: The temporal relation of one interval to the interval it is linked to.

Unsigned.name: FinishToStart
Unsigned.documentation: The next interval immediately begins after the previous interval (the default interpretation).

Unsigned.name: FinishToFinish
Unsigned.documentation: The next interval ends at the same time as the previous interval.

Unsigned.name: StartToFinish
Unsigned.documentation: The next interval finishes immediately before the previous interval (i.e., each interval in a sequence points to the interval immediately preceding it in time).

Unsigned.name: StartToStart
Unsigned.documentation: The next interval begins at the same time as the previous interval.
